questions.question:
Question 1: A child is found to have paralysis due to poliovirus infection. Which of the following is false 
regarding the paralysis seen?

options.a: It is an upper motor neuron type
options.c: Strenuous physical exercise during the onset exaggerates the paralysis
options.d: It can be caused by polio vaccination

questions.explanation:
Poliovirus mainly affects the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and medulla oblongata (cranial 
nerve nuclei), causing lower motor neuron (LMN) type of paralysis. It damages motor and 
autonomic nerves; sensory nerves are not involved. Poliovirus is a non-enveloped, positive-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Picornaviridae 
family. Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) are known. Ages 6 months to 5 
years are most commonly affected. The virus is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and has an 
incubation period of 8-12 days. Humans are the only known reservoir for the polioviruses. The virus colonizes and replicates in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into the blood via 
regional lymph nodes. In blood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral 
nerves, finally reaching the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. Most cases are subclinical. Some have minor illnesses like fever, sore throat, headache, and 
malaise. It can present as non-paralytic polio (aseptic meningitis) or paralytic polio (flaccid 
paralysis with absent deep tendon reflexes). Most frequently, the completely affected muscle is 
the tibialis anterior. It is asymmetric paralysis which is more severe if strenuous physical exercise 
occurred during the onset of paralysis. Death usually occurs due to respiratory paralysis. Vaccination schedule for polio: 286 
Sold by @itachibot • Live attenuated: oral polio vaccine (OPV) (Sabin) at birth (day 0); then boosters at 6, 10, and 14 
weeks and at 15-18 months; additional doses till 5 years • Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) (Salk) given intradermally; two fractional doses at 6 and 14 weeks 
as well as 9 months of age.

questions.question:
Question 2: An outbreak of paralytic polio has occurred in Nigeria. Which of the following is the most 
likely type to cause such outbreaks?
questions.explanation:
Most of the outbreaks of paralytic polio are caused by the type 1 virus. Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) of poliovirus are known. Poliovirus type 1 
has historically been the predominant cause of poliomyelitis worldwide and continues to be 
transmitted in endemic areas. Most infections with poliovirus are asymptomatic. Rarely, patients can have the following 
presentations: • Abortive poliomyelitis - a minor illness, manifested by fever, malaise, sore throat, or headache. • Non-paralytic poliomyelitis - manifested by aseptic meningitis. • Paralytic poliomyelitis - aseptic meningitis followed by severe back, neck, and muscle pain with 
rapid/gradual onset of motor weakness. It is the least common presentation of poliovirus 
infection. Wild poliovirus type 2 was eradicated in 1999. Until 2015, over 90% of cVDPV (circulating 
vaccine-derived polioviruses) cases were due to the type 2 component in OPV. Bivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) contains serotypes 1 and 3. Serotype 2 has been removed, as it is 
implicated in the pathogenesis of cVDPV and occasionally vaccine-associated paralytic polio 
(VAPP). Note: On 25 April 2016, India switched from trivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) to bivalent OPV; this day 
is called the National switch day.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following signs may be seen in a child with polio?
questions.explanation:
All of the above signs may be seen in a child suffering from polio. • Tripod sign - When the child is asked to sit up unassisted, the child assumes the tripod posture. • Kiss the knee sign - The child cannot kiss the knee due to spine stiffness. • Head drop sign - A hand is placed under the patient's shoulder and the trunk is raised. Usually, 
the head will also raise, but in the case of poliomyelitis, the head drops backward.

questions.question:
Question 4: You have been appointed as a member of the acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance team. 
What age groups would you target for surveillance?
questions.explanation:
287 
Sold by @itachibot Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance is done in children from 0-15 years. Every case of acute flaccid paralysis in any child under 15 years is to be reported promptly. Fecal 
samples of all these cases are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72 
hours of collection at 4–8 degree Celcius or frozen at -20 degree Celcius. This process is known as 
the reverse cold chain. The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis include the following: • Non-polio enteroviruses • West Nile virus • Guillan–Barre syndrome • Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis

questions.question: Question 5: When was India declared polio-free by WHO?
questions.explanation: India was certified polio-free on March 27, 2014. • The last case of polio reported in India was in January 2011. • Type 2 virus was declared eradicated in September 2015. • Switch from trivalent to bivalent vaccine was done in India in April 2016.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not a component of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023 by WHO?

options.a: Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection
options.b: Separation of polio surveillance and vaccine preventable disease surveillance
options.d: Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)

questions.explanation:
Integration, not separation, of polio surveillance with vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) 
surveillance, is a part of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023. Goals of the Polio Endgame Strategy 2019–2023 Goal One: Eradication • Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV) • Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection 
and eliminate the risk of emergence of future VDPVs Goal two: Integration • Contribute to strengthening immunization and health systems to help achieve and sustain polio 
eradication • Ensure sensitive poliovirus surveillance through integration with comprehensive 
vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) and communicable disease surveillance systems • Prepare for and respond to future outbreaks and emergencies Goal Three: Certification & Containment • Certify eradication of WPV • Contain all polioviruses 288 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: At your vaccination center, you have noticed increased reporting of vaccine-associated 
paralytic polio (VAPP). Which of the following statement is true regarding this adverse effect 
of the vaccine?

options.a: It occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine
options.b: It is more likely to occur if the first dose was parenteral inactivated polio vaccine
options.c: It Is most likely to occur if given on the same day as yellow fever vaccine
options.d: It is more likely to occur if multiple parenteral injections have been given at the same time

questions.explanation:
Vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine 
(OPV). VAPP is said to occur if: • Acute flaccid paralysis occurred 4 to 40 days after receiving OPV, and residual weakness lasted 
for more than 60 days after the onset of paralysis. • Isolation of vaccine-related poliovirus in any stool samples and no isolation of wild poliovirus 
from any stool samples. Note: • VAPP: Vaccine-associated paralytic polio • VDPV: Vaccine-derived polio virus. A very rare strain of polio virus, genetically changed from 
the original strain contained in OPV. • cVDPV: circulating vaccine-derived polio virus. In areas of low vaccination coverage, a VDPV 
strain may revert to a form that can cause cases of paralytic polio, leading to an outbreak. This 
form is called a cVDPV.

questions.question:
Question 8: While volunteering in an orphanage that takes care of disabled kids, you notice the typical 
hand-knee gait of polio in a child. He walks by putting his right hand on his right lower thigh 281 
Sold by @itachibot while stepping forward. Which of the following muscle weakness is responsible for this 
finding?
questions.explanation:
Polio commonly affects the quadriceps, and weakness of the quadriceps leads to the buckling 
(bending) of the knee while walking or bearing weight on the leg. So, in order to walk, the person 
has to prevent the buckling of the knee by supporting with the hand, producing a hand-knee gait. Examination findings in paralytic polio: A. In the early stage • Asymmetric motor paralysis - involvement of affected muscles is haphazard. No associated 
sensory loss. • Commonly affects the lower limbs • Most common muscle affected - Quadriceps, although it is most often partially paralyzed • Most common muscle to undergo complete paralysis - Tibialis anterior • The most affected muscle in the hand - Opponens pollicis • Bulbar/bulbospinal polio - It is a rare but life-threatening disease affecting the motor neurons of 
the medulla and resulting in the involvement of the respiratory and cardiovascular centers, which 
may cause death. B. In the late-stage • Weakness, wasting, and deformity of the limbs • At the hip-flexion-abduction-external rotation 289 
Sold by @itachibot • At the knee, flexion deformity is common; in severe cases, there is triple deformity: flexion, 
posterior subluxation, and external rotation • At the foot, the commonest deformity is equino-varus. Other deformities - equinovalgus, 
calcaneo-valgus, and calcaneo-varus • In the upper limb: affects the shoulder and elbow, hand muscles are spared.

questions.question:
Question 9: Serological testing of a neonate born to an HIV-infected mother turned out positive. Which of 
the following is the most likely route by which the newborn might have acquired the 
infection?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of HIV infection in an infant is the intrapartum transmission. The mechanism of intrapartum transmission appears to be mucosal exposure to infected blood 
and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal. The intrauterine contractions during active 
labor/delivery could also increase the risk of late microtransfusions. Routes of HIV transmission in an infant: • Intrauterine • Intrapartum - most common • Breastfeeding - least common Risk factors for vertical transmission: • High maternal viremia (most important) • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks) • Vitamin A deficiency • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours) • Low birth weight • Low maternal CD4 count

questions.question:
Question 10: You are evaluating children infected with HIV in a village, where there is little awareness 
about HIV and its treatment. Which of the following will be the most common presenting 
feature in these children?
questions.explanation:
Failure to thrive is the universal finding in children with HIV. Important features in HIV-infected children include the following: • Presenting features - failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, oral thrush, chronic diarrhea, or 
respiratory symptoms. • Most common AIDS-defining illness (opportunistic infection) in children - Pneumocystis carinii 
pneumonia • Most common fungal infection - oral candidiasis • Recurrent and chronic bacterial infections (especially, Streptococcus pneumoniae) • Most common GI disease - chronic/recurrent diarrhea with malabsorption • Most common renal disease - nephrotic syndrome 290 
Sold by @itachibot • Most common hematological manifestation - anemia • Most common neoplasms - non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, primary CNS lymphoma, and 
leiomyosarcomas

questions.question: Question 11: Match the following HIV cases with their respective stages.
questions.explanation: Correct match is: 1-a, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b. A 5-year old child with persistent diarrhea for 20 days - Stage 3 An asymptomatic 2-year-old with persistent generalized lymphadenopathy - Stage 1 A 7-year-old with recurrent oral ulcers and persistent parotid enlargement - Stage 2 A 4-year-old with HIV-associated cardiomyopathy - Stage 4

questions.question:
Question 12: A 28-year-old woman in labor comes to the emergency department at 37 weeks gestation. She 
never had a prenatal checkup. The routine screening revealed she is HIV-positive. Which of 
the following method is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV?

options.c: Administration of ART prophylaxis to baby after birth

questions.explanation:
Vaginal cleansing before delivery is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV. Methods to prevent perinatal transmission of HIV include the following: • Antiretroviral therapy (ART): • Single-dose nevirapine at the onset of labor followed by a single dose to the newborn within 72 
hours of birth. • Zidovudine can also be used from the 2nd trimester onwards throughout pregnancy and for 6 
weeks after birth to infancy. • Breastfed infants should receive NVP for 6 weeks if the mother is receiving cART, or NVP for the 
duration of breastfeeding if the mother is not on therapy. Formula-fed infants in resource-limited 
countries should receive ZDV bid or NVP qd for 6 weeks. • Elective cesarean section* • Breastfeeding: Usually contraindicated, except in developing countries where breastfeeding may 
be continued for 6 months. *Note: Maternal cART is documented to decrease the rate of perinatal HIV-1 transmission to <2%, and 
<1% if the mother’s viral RNA level is <1,000 copies/mL at delivery. Thus, elective C-section 
at 38 weeks of gestation should be considered only for women whose viral load is >1,000 
copies/ mL in late gestation, to further reduce the risk of vertical transmission. Guidelines for the use of antiretroviral drugs during C-section are as follows: • For elective (planned) C-section, ART should be given prior to the operation. • Women on lifelong ART should continue their standard ART regimen. • In case of emergency C-section in pregnant women who are not on ART, the three-drug regimen 
should be started before the surgery and continued thereafter. 291 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient is started on HAART treatment for HIV. Her CD4 count is 150 cells/l. She 
developed a fever and her symptoms worsened during her first week of treatment. Which of 
the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) is characterized by an increased 
inflammatory response to subclinical opportunistic infections after initiating retroviral therapy. Features seen are fever, worsening of opportunistic infections, new manifestations like 
lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates. It typically occurs within 1st few weeks of starting 
therapy. It commonly occurs in patients with progressive disease, or severe CD4 + T-lymphocyte 
depletion.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is an indication to start ART in children, as per the WHO guidelines?

options.a: <11 months infant of CD4 count < 1500 cells/mm3

questions.explanation:
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be initiated in all children with HIV, regardless of clinical 
stage or CD4 cell count, as per the latest WHO recommendations 2016. Also, cotrimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended for infants, children, and adolescents with HIV, 
irrespective of their clinical and immune conditions.

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is not a part of the 2025 HIV targets of Global AIDS Strategy 
2021-2026?

options.a: 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health service
options.b: 90% of people living with HIV recieve preventive treatment for TB
options.c: 95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads.
options.d: 75% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of

questions.explanation:
292 
Sold by @itachibot 95%(not 75%) of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation 
of breastfeeding is part of the High level 2025 targets of Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026 High-level 2025 targets • 95% of people at risk of HIV infection have access to and use appropriate, prioritized, 
person-centered, and effective combination prevention options. • 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health service 
needs met. • 95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads. • 95% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of 
breastfeeding • 75% of all children living with HIV have suppressed viral loads by 2023 (interim target) • 95–95–95 testing and treatment targets are achieved within all subpopulations, age groups, and 
geographic settings, including children living with HIV. • 90% of people living with HIV receive preventive treatment for TB. • 90% of people living with HIV and people at risk are linked to people-centered and 
context-specific integrated services for other communicable diseases, noncommunicable diseases, 
sexual health and gender-based violence, mental health, drug and substance use, and other 
services they need for their overall health and wellbeing. The Strategy keeps people at the center and aims to unite countries, communities, and partners 
across and beyond the HIV response to take prioritized actions to accelerate progress towards the 
vision of zero new HIV infections, zero discrimination, and zero AIDS-related deaths. This Strategy lays out a framework for transformative action to reduce the inequalities by 2025 
and to get every country and every community on track to end AIDS by 2030.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 26-year-old pregnant labourer who is HIV-positive delivers a healthy male baby. She was 
advised ART previously but has been non-compliant with her treatment. What is 
recommended by NACO with regards to feeding the baby?
questions.explanation:
NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the infant feeding choice in the first 6 months. This 
is irrespective of the fact that the mother is on ART or the infant is provided with ARV 
prophylaxis for 6 weeks. Breast-feeding and replacement feed simultaneously (mixed feeds) in the first 6 months should 
not be done, as it leads to mucosal abrasions in the gut of the baby, thereby facilitating HIV entry. Breast-feeding should not be stopped abruptly. Only in situations where breastfeeding cannot be 
done (maternal death, severe maternal illness) or individual mother’s choice (at her own risk), 
then exclusive replacement feeding which is safe, sustainable, affordable and feasible can be 
started. In resource-rich settings/developed countries, exclusive alternative formulations are 
recommended. 293 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: You are an intern posted in the postnatal ward of a hospital. You receive an HIV-positive 
patient on PND-1. Which of the following tests would you use to detect HIV in the baby?
questions.explanation:
HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR. NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18months Antibody assays (e.g., ELISA) that are commonly used for HIV testing in adults and older children 
are not reliable in infants and young children because of the persistence of transplacentally 
acquired maternal antibodies until 18 months after birth. For this reason, HIV virologic testing 
(PCR) must be performed using tests that detect HIV DNA or RNA. Scheduled repeated testing is 
necessary because test sensitivity increases with time from HIV virus exposure. Also, a very recent 
infection will not be detectable by PCR. Cord blood should not be used for testing because of the possibility of contamination of the 
sample with maternal blood.

questions.question: Question 19: The image given below depicts the mode of infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows, infection through fecal oral route, colonization of the organism, and 
replication in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into blood via regional lymph nodes. In 
blood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral nerves, finally reaching the 
anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. The pathogenesis expalined above is that of polio infection. Option A: Infection with Campylobacter jejuni is implicated in the pathogenesis of Guillain–Barre 
syndrome, where the antibodies against C. jejuni cross-react with the gangliosides (GM1) in the 
peripheral nervous system. Option B: Hepatitis A infection occurs through the fecal-oral route, and the virus replicates in the 
GI mucosa and is then transported to the liver. Option D: Rotavirus causes diarrhea by causing malabsorption. 294 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Kenny packs are used in the treatment of
questions.explanation:
Kenny packs are used in the treatment of poliomyelitis. Treatment of poliomyelitis includes the following: • Symptomatic and supportive treatment: Analgesics, bed rest, and physiotherapy • Sister Kenny’s treatment: Hot moist packs applied to muscles to relieve pain and spasm • Optimum positioning of limbs to prevent deformity • Management of pure bulbar poliomyelitis consists of maintaining the airway and avoiding the 
risk of aspiration. 295 
Sold by @itachibot Pediatric Bacterial and Parasitic Infections
